#Text=[0053] FIG. 12a illustrates a preferred gray scale projector embodiment.
#Text=The SLM is of the types that do not depend on polarization of illuminating light, such as DMD or TMA or the like.
#Text=Again, the drawing assumes the SLM as transmissive type for convenience of explanation.
#Text=The polarization beamsplitter 1220, TIR prism 223 and two reflectors 224 and 225 separate the illumination beam into two paths.
#Text=The display panel 130 is therefore defined with two sub-panels, each illuminated with light of a different polarization (P or S).
#Text=After the projection lens, a similar optical setup merges the two sub-panels on a projection screen at a distance.
#Text=A second aperture plate 911 is inserted into one of the two paths to create scaled illumination on the two sub-panels.
#Text=For example, if on each sub-panel one pixel contains four sub-pixels of equal size, then the gray level of one pixel is 5 (0-4).
#Text=If the illumination intensity over the two sub-panels are scaled as 1:5, then the combined gray level is 25 (5.times.5).
#Text=[0054] FIG. 12b illustrates still another preferred embodiment of gray scale projector.
#Text=The display panel is the type based on polarization, such as a FLC SLM.
#Text=The setup is basically similar to that of FIG. 12a, except for a few additional components.
#Text=Polarization difference is used for separation of illumination paths and for merging of the two sub-panels.
#Text=However, because the display image is also based on difference of polarization, some special treatments with use of additional components are needed.
#Text=First, the images on the two sub-panels are defined to always have different polarization states.
#Text=That is, when sub-panel 130A displays images of P state and background of S state, then sub-panel 130B displays images of S state and background of P state.
#Text=In this way, the images from the two sub-panels can be separated by the polarizing beamsplitter 1221 into two paths and then merged together at a distance 180.
#Text=A 1/2-wave plate 1265 is therefore needed to turn the polarization axis of one of the two images 90 degree, so that both images are projected with the same polarization state.
#Text=A screen aperture 1212 is also needed to block unwanted half images from reaching the screen.
#Text=Again, the polarization rotator 1270 and is used for projecting inverted image frames.

#Text=[0055] The method of combining and merging images from a display panel of color triad type structure described above applies not only to color triads or sub-panels structure created by Pattern Projection techniques, but also to any display panel with built-in color triads or build-in separate and isolated sub-panels.

#Text=When sub-panels are defined as separate and isolated regions on an SLM, one can even illuminate all sub-panels with a white light and then use dichroic color mirrors to filter out desired color from each sub-panels and then merge them into one image.
#Text=The disadvantage of this method is that it throws away 2/3 light.
#Text=Similarly, in a gray scale projector such as the one depicted in FIG. 12a, the SLM can also be illuminated with non-polarized light.
#Text=The merging optics after the projection lens 160 can still filter out the desired sub-panel images and merge them into one image, with 1/2 light being thrown away.
#Text=[0056] In addition to using arrays of micro-lens, there are many other ways of creating a pattern of light spots or stripes.
#Text=Depending on how the light is manipulated, there can be three broad categories of ways:
#Text=[0057] (1) Using an array of light re-directing elements: A light re-directing element changes the direction of light to form the desired light pattern.

#Text=One example is spherical micro-lens, which can be used to create arrays of circular spots, as already described in FIG. 1a Another example is micro-cylindrical lens, as illustrated in FIG. 13a, which can generate arrays of stripes, as illustrated in FIG. 3d.
#Text=Stacking two arrays of micro- cylindrical lens in orthogonal directions, as illustrated in FIG. 13b, can generate square light spots as the ones depicted in FIG. 6 b & c.
#Text=Another example is an optical fiber bundle, wherein each optical fiber can represent a light spot when the opposite end is illuminated, as illustrated in FIG. 13c.
#Text=An array of concave reflective surface can also create an array of light spots or stripes, as illustrated in FIG. 13d.
